About Peter

My first payday as a writer. 
Forced Start
 
I was born at home, a suburban semi in Whitton, Middlesex, in 1936, ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œwith instrumentsÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½, as my mother used to say, and it didnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t mean violins playing. In midwife-speak, I was turned down, a salutary experience for a future writer. 

Earliest significant memory is a wartime one from 1944: being collected from an air-raid shelter at school and told our home had been destroyed by a V1 Flying Bomb. Miraculously my family escaped ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ brothers John and Andrew crawled out of the rubble, having survived under a Morrison table-shelter ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ although our neighbours in the other half of the house were killed. 

After the bombing we were billeted with a farmer and his family in the West Country, an episode that influenced Rough Cider, my book about the memories of an evacuee. 


Enjoy!
